document.docTitle: Descriptions of two new Species of Goniozus Förster, 1856 (Hymenoptera: Bethylidae) associated with insect induced plant galls from India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Descriptions of two new Species of Goniozus Förster, 1856 (Hymenoptera: Bethylidae) associated with insect induced plant galls from India

emphasis.docTitle:
Descriptions of two new Species of
Goniozus
Förster, 1856
( Hymenoptera : Bethylidae ) associated with insect induced plant galls from India

subSection.paragraph:
SHREEVIHAR SANTHOSH
1
& AVINJIKKATTU PARAMBIL RANJITH
Department of Zoology, Malabar Christian College, Kozhikode (Affiliated to University of Calicut ), 673001 , Kerala, India . E-mail: nairssanthosh@gmail.com; ridhuranjith@gmail.com

Two new species of the genus
Goniozus
viz.,
Goniozus inauditus Santhosh
sp. nov.
and
G. kuriani Santhosh
sp. nov.
associated with insect induced plant galls from South India are described. The parasitic relationship of
Goniozus
with the nonlepidopteran hosts living in the concealed habitats and their association with insect induced plant galls and its inhabitants are reviewed. The possible host range extension of
Goniozus
is commented.

Key words:
Goniozus
, plant galls, nonlepidopteran hosts, South India .

Goniozus
Förster, 1856
is a highly speciose genus, consists of 172 species worldwide (
Gordh & Móczár 1990
;
Gordh & Witethom 1994
;
Krombein 1996
; Terayama 1994 , 2004 ,
2006
;
Xu et al. 2002
;
Santhosh & Narendran 2009
;
Lim & Lee 2012
).
Goniozus
is represented by 53 species from Oriental region, out of which 37 were reported from Indian subcontinent (
Santhosh & Narendran 2009
;
Lim & Lee 2012
). The biology of
Goniozus
species is extending within the families of microlepidopterans (e.g. Gelechiidae , Oecophoridae , Pyralidae and Totricidae) (
Gordh & Móczár 1990
) except one report of
G. microstigmi Melo & Evans
has been reared from a brood cell of a crabronid wasp,
Microstigmus xylicola Melo
, a predator of nymphal Thysanoptera (
Melo & Evans 1993
;
Polaszek & Krombein 1994
). Here, we describe two new species of
Goniozus
associated with the insect induced leaf galls from South India along with an account of host association within the concealed microhabitat.

Leaf galls of
Memecylon umbellatum Burm.
f. (
Fig 1
A) (The Plant List 2015 ) and
Syzygium cumini
(L.) Skeels (
Fig 1
B) were collected from Sowpnabitta (Karnataka) and Trivandrum (Kerala) respectively. The galls were identified by using
Mani ( 2000 )
and reared in 1000 ml glass beakers for the possible emergence of parasitoids.

The terms for integument sculpture follow
Harris ( 1979 )
and most of measurements and morphological terms adopted in this paper follow
Evans ( 1964 )
and
Terayama ( 2006 )
and the abbreviation as follows: AOL, anteroposterior ocellar line;
DAO
, maximum diameter of anterior ocelli; EV, post-orbital distance measured as distance from top of eye to posterior margin of vertex, measured in lateral view; F 1 , F 2 and F 11 , funicular segments 1, 2 and 11 respectively; FWL, maximum length of fore wing; HE, maximum length of eye in lateral view; LH, maximum length of head from clypeal margin to vertex in full dorsal view; M, median vein; OOL, ocello-ocular line; POL, posterior-ocellar line; WF, minimum distance between the eyes in full dorsal view; WH, maximum width of head including eyes in full dorsal view; WOT, width of ocellar triangle; SI, profemur sphericity index; VRN, Voucher Number.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 . Insect induced leaf galls on A)
Memecylon umbellatum
induced by
Crotonothrips
sp. B)
Syzygium cumini
induced by
Trioza jambolanae Crawford.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Goniozus
Förster, 1856
: 95
–96. Type species:
Bethylus claripennis Förster
, by subsequent designation. (
Ashmead 1893, 45: 72
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Parasierola
Cameron 1883
, 197. Type species:
Parasierola testaceicornis Cameron
, by monotypy. Synonymized by
Evans 1978
.

Progoniozus
Kieffer 1905
: 105 . Type species: Perisemus floridanus Ashmead, by original designation. Synonymized by
Evans 1978
.

Perisierola
Kieffer 1914
: 533 . Type species:
Parasierola gallicola
Kieffer 1905
, by subsequent designation (
Muesebeck & Walkley, 1951
). Synonymized by
Evans, 1978
.

Material examined . Holotype ♀,. ‘ INDIA : Karnataka, Sringeri, Souwpnabitta,
13 ° 23.59 'N
75 ° 47.30 'E
, 689 msl, 227 .
iv. 2007
, rearing, ex.
Crotonothrips
sp. induced leaf galls on
Memecylon umbellatum , Moist Deciduous Forest, Community Managed Forests, M. Nasser
, leg., VRN 160 ( ZSIK )’.
Paratypes .
1 ♀, ‘ INDIA : Kerala, Areyadatupalam, 1 km E Kozhikode ,
11 ° 16.16 'N
75 ° 47.30 'E
, 8 msl,
22 .iv. 2006
, K. Bindu leg., VRN 131 ’; 1 ♀, Malappuram, Thenjipalam,
11 °07.44'N
75 ° 53.44 'E
, 67 msl,
6 .viii. 1988
, T.C. Narendran leg., VRN 114 ’ ( ZSIK ); 1 ♀, ‘ INDIA : Kerala, collection locality unknown,
2–6 .i. 1993
, unknown leg., VRN 16 ’ ( ZSIK ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 .
Goniozus inauditus Santhosh
sp. nov.
, ♀, holotype A) Habitus, lateral view; B) Head & mesosoma, lateral view; C) Head, anterior view; D) Mesosoma, dorsal view; E) Metasoma, dorsal view; F) Forewing & hindwing.

FIGURE 3 . Gall inhabitants of
Memecylon umbellatum
A)
Crotonothrips
sp. B)
Carpelimus
sp.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis . Head distinctly longer than wide (
Fig. 2
C), WH 0.83–0.85 × LH; compressed in lateral aspect (
Fig. 2
B), 1.72 × as long as wide; frons and vertex strongly coriaceous, with scattered shallow punctures (
Fig. 2
C); gena smooth and polished; malar space distinct (
Fig. 2
B); malar groove present; eye sparsely setose, setae as long as diameter of single facet; posterior ocelli contiguous with vertex margin; ocelli in obtuse triangle; OOL 1.09–1.1 × WOT; WF = HE; EV 0.47–0.55 × HE; antero-median smooth propodeal triangle absent; median smooth longitudinal stripe not elevated, extending to posterior margin of propodeal disc, wider in posterior half (
Fig. 2
D); forewing with subtriangular areolet (
Fig. 2
F), vein M, SM profusely setose; profemur 1.92 × as long as wide.
Description . Female ( holotype ) Length 3.08 mm ; FWL 1.66 mm .

Colour. Body brown to black, abdomen brown at apex; mandible, teeth dark brown; antenna yellow, terminal final segments light brown; coxae, femora light brown, other segments yellow, wing hyaline; prostigma, pterostigma, costa, subcosta light brown, other veins straw coloured.

Head. Head distinctly longer than wide, WH 0.85 × LH; 1.72 × as long as wide in lateral aspect; frons and vertex strongly coriaceous, with scattered shallow punctures (
Fig. 2
C); gena smooth and polished; vestiture moderately long, 0.06 mm ; profuse, decumbent; setae on vertex distinctly longer than setae on head, longest being 0.15 mm ; anterior clypeal margin strongly produced, bluntly angulated, acute; clypeal carina 0.73 × HE, strong, arcuate in profile, extending onto front as low carina slightly beyond posterior scrobal margin; scrobe carinate; mandible stout with four short, blunt teeth, ventral most straight and longest; WF 0.48 x LH; WF = HE; EV 0.5 × HE; LH 1.74 × HE; malar space distinct; malar groove present; eye sparsely setose, setae minute, as long as diameter of single facet; ocelli in obtuse triangle; posterior ocelli contiguous with vertex margin; OOL 1.09 × WOT; POL: AOL:
DAO
= 4 : 2 : 2 ; vertex straight in full dorsal view, acutely, smoothly curving to occiput, ecarinate; relative lengths of first five antennal segments in ratio of about 7 : 3.5 : 2.5 : 3 : 3 ; scape 1.4 × as long as wide, 2 × as long as pedicel; pedicel longer than F 1 ; F 1 segment as long as wide; F 2 –F 7 wider than long; F 8 –F 9 as long wide; F 10 –F 11 longer than wide; antenna slightly shorter than head in full dorsal view ( 25 : 27 ) (
Fig. 2
C).

Mesosoma. Pronotum, mesonotum, and scutellum strongly coriaceous uniformly (
Fig. 2
D); vestiture long, profuse, decumbent; sparse on scutellum, mesonotum; pronotal disc 0.55 × as long as wide; mesonotum with complete parapsidal furrow (
Fig. 2
D); notauli absent; scutellum with a pair of slits at base connected by one weak narrow groove; propodeal disc 0.55 × as long as wide, smoothly inclined to lateral margin; basal median smooth triangle absent; median smooth longitudinal band not elevated, extending to posterior margin of propodeal disc, wider in posterior half; rest of propodeal disc and declivity strongly coriaceous; transverse propodeal carina medially interrupted broadly (
Fig. 2
D); forewing 2.8 × as long as wide; areolet present, subtriangular in shape (
Fig. 2
F); vein M, SM profusely setose, areolet sparsely setose; speculum profusely setose; profemur 1.92 × as long as wide; SI 10.74 .

Metasoma. Tergites completely smooth and polished (
Fig. 2
E); T 1 –T 3 with few setae restricted to lateral margin; other tergites sparsely setose all across dorsal side; metasoma distinctly longer than mesosoma, shorter than head plus mesosoma (
Fig. 2
A).
Male . Unknown.

Ecology and Biology . Ex. leaf galls on
Memecylon umbellatum Burm.
f. (Melastomaceae) induced by
Crotonothrips
sp. (
Fig. 3
A) (
Raman & Ananthakrishnan 1985
); associate host:
Carpelimus
sp. ( Staphylinidae ) (
Fig. 3
B).

Etymology . The species epithet is after the Latin word
inauditus
meaning new.
Variation . See table 1 for the morphometric ratios of the type materials examined.

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Morphometric ratios of the type material examined.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution . India (Karnataka; Kerala).

Discussion .
Goniozus inauditus Santhosh
sp. nov.
comes close to
G. nephantidis (Muesebeck)
, but differ in having ocular setae as long as diameter of single facet, scape 2 × pedicel, WF = HE, EV 0.62 × HE, mandible black brown and antenna shorter than head in full dorsal view (
Fig. 2
C), whereas in
G. nephantidis
ocular setae 2 × as long as diameter of single facet, scape longer than 2 × pedicel, WF 1.15–1.20 × HE, EV 0.36–0.47 × HE, mandible black and antenna longer than head in full dorsal view.
( Figs 4 , 5 )

Material examined .
Holotype
♀, ‘ INDIA : Kerala, Trivandrum, Art gallery campus,
08° 30.31 'N
76 ° 57.16 'E
, 50 msl,
20 .i. 2008
, rearing, ex.
Trioza jambolanae Crawford
induced leaf galls on
Syzygium cumini
(L) Skeels; M. Sheeba leg., VRN 186 ( ZSIK )’.
Paratypes .
2 ♀ data same as holotype , VRN 161 , VRN 187 ; 1 ♀, ‘ INDIA : Karnataka, Makutta, 30 kms from Virajpet,
12 °04.39'N
75 ° 43.37 'E
, 119 msl,
28 .vi. 2006
, rearing, Sarasija leg., on plant host
Dipterocarpus indicus Bedd.
, VRN 28 ( ZSIK )’.

Diagnosis . Head distinctly longer than wide (
Fig. 4
C), WH 0.77–0.81 × LH; compressed in lateral aspect, 2 × as long as wide; sides behind eye are parallel before curving inwards to vertex (
Fig. 4
B); clypeal apical margin weakly produced, obtuse; antenna slightly shorter than head in full dorsal view; pedicel longer than F 1 ; malar space distinct; malar groove present; ocelli triangle acute; posterior ocelli equal to or more than 0.5 × its diameter away from vertex margin; EV 0.72–0.83 × HE; OOL 0.61–0.67 × WOT; vertex emarginated; anteromedian propodeal area rectangular, smooth, not elevated (
Fig. 4
D); forewing with areolet (
Fig. 4
F), vein M, SM sparsely setose; profemur 1.92 × as long as wide.
Description : Female ( holotype ) Length 2.75 mm ; FWL 1.75 mm .

Colour. Body black, abdomen dark brown; mandible black, teeth brown; antenna yellow, terminal five segments brown, last being darkest; legs yellow; coxae, femora with dorsal margin brown, wing hyaline, subcosta, prostigma, pterostigma brown, others veins colourless.

Head. Head longer than wide (
Fig. 4
C), WH 0.81 × LH; 2 × as long as wide in lateral aspect; sides behind eye are parallel before curving inwards to slightly emarginated vertex; frons and vertex coriaceous with scattered shallow punctures (
Fig. 4
C); gena smooth and polished (
Fig. 4
B); vestiture short, sparse, suberect; setae on vertex not distinctly longer than setae on rest of head, longest being 0.068 mm ; anterior clypeal margin weakly produced, obtuse; clypeal carina strong and weakly arcuate in profile, extending onto front as a low carina up to level of posterior scrobal margin; scrobe ecarinate; mandible robust, four teeth, ventral most straight longest teeth; WF 0.48 × LH; WF = HE; EV 0.83 × HE; LH 2.3 × HE; malar space distinct; malar groove present; eye sparsely setose, setae minute, shorter than diameter of single facet; ocelli in acute triangle; posterior ocelli separated from vertex margin by half its diameter; OOL 0.67 × WOT; POL: AOL:
DAO
= 3.5 : 2 : 1.8 ; vertex smoothly curved to occiput, ecarinate; relative lengths of first five antennal segments are in the ratio of about 6 : 3 : 2.3 : 2.3 : 2.7 ; scape 1.33 × as long as wide, 2 × as long as pedicel; pedicel longer than F 1 ; all segments wider than long except terminal single segment; antenna slightly shorter than head in full dorsal view ( 27 : 29 ) (
Fig. 4
C).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4 .
Goniozus kuriani Santhosh
sp. nov.
, ♀, holotype A. Habitus, lateral view; B. Head, lateral view; C. Head, anterior view; D. Mesosoma, dorsal view; E. Mesosoma & legs, lateral view; F. Fore wing.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Mesosoma. Pronotum, mesonotum, and scutellum uniformly coriaceous, with scattered shallow punctures (
Fig. 4
D); vestiture short, sparse, decumbent; pronotal disc 0.52 × as long as wide; mesonotum with complete parapsidal furrow, notauli absent; scutellum with a pair of basal pits at base connected by a narrow transverse groove, propodeal disc 0.53 × as long as wide, smoothly inclined to lateral margin (
Fig. 4
D); basal median propodeal triangle absent, median smooth band, not elevated, extending beyond posterior margin of propodeal disc (
Fig. 4
D); rest of propodeal disc, declivity coriaceous; posterior transverse propodeal carina broadly interrupted medially; forewing 2.88 × as long as wide; areolet present (
Fig. 4
F); vein M, SM with single row of setae; areolet and speculum sparsely setose; profemur 1.92 × as long as wide; SI 7.67 .

Metasoma. Tergites smooth and polished, T 1 –T 3 with few setae restricted to lateral margin; other tergites sparsely setose all across dorsal side; metasoma distinctly longer than mesosoma ( 54 : 40 ), shorter than head plus mesosoma ( 54 : 67 ) (
Fig. 4
A).
Male . Unknown.

Ecology and Biology . Ex. unidentified leaf galls of
Syzygium cumini
(L.) Skeels ( Myrtaceae ). The species is also collected from the plant host,
Dipterocarpus indicus Bedd.
( Dipterocarpaceae ).

Etymology . The species epithet is after Chandy Kurian, who worked on Indian Bethylidae during
1952–1955
.
Distribution . India (Karnataka; Kerala).
Variation . In paratypes , OOL 0.62 × WOT and EV 0.72 × HE. See table 2 for the morphometric ratios of the type material examined.

Discussion .
Goniozus kuriani
sp. nov.
is closely related to
G. valvolicola Krombein
reported from Sri Lanka in having vertex emarginate, scrobe ecarinate, M, SM sparsely setose, posterior ocelli equal to or more than 0.5 × its diameter away from vertex margin and EV 0.75–0.85 × HE.
Goniozus kuriani
sp. nov.
differs from
G. valvolicola Krombein
in having ocellar triangle acute, forefemur 1.92 × as long as wide, OOL 0.66 × WOT, clypeal apical margin weakly produced and obtuse, anteromedian rectangular smooth propodeal area, but not elevated and pedicel longer than F 1 , whereas in
G. valvolicola
ocellar triangle in right angle, forefemur 2.07 × as long as wide, OOL 1.54–1.58 × WOT, clypeal apical margin strongly produced, acute, antero-median triangular smooth propodeal area is elevated and pedicel is shorter than F 1 .

caption.paragraph: TABLE 2. Morphometric ratios of the type materials examined.

heading.emphasis:
Association of
Goniozus
with insect induced plant galls

subSubSection.paragraph:
Generally
Goniozus
species are relatively generalists in host-parasitoid association. Many of them are gregarious parasitoids of larval Lepidoptera . However, there are a few anomalous or questionable host records of
Goniozus
.
Nagy ( 1976 )
reported
Goniozus gallicolla (Kieffer)
and
G. plugarui Nagy
attacking pupae of their lepidopteran hosts, but the ‘pupal parasite’ might be the parasitoids reared from larvae after it had spun the cocoon and not yet pupated (
Polaszek & Krombein 1994
). Apart from the lepidopteran hosts, the species
Goniozus
exhibit an extended host association as they were reared from Coleoptera .
Richards ( 1956 )
reported a tentatively identified G. g e s t ro i (Keiffer) reared from larvae of an anobiid beetle,
Lasioderma
sp. This is similar to most of the lepidopteran host associations of
Goniozus ,
where the hosts share a moderate degree of concealment. The present study supports this.

The new species
G. inauditus
sp. nov.
was reared from
Crotonothrips
sp. induced leaf galls of
Memecylon umbellatum
and this new species is found to be associated with
Carpelimus
sp. as gall inhabitants.
Goniozus inauditus
sp. nov.
might have a parasitic association with the staphylinid as there is one authentic record of a coleopteran host ( Anobiidae ) for
Goniozus
by
Richards ( 1956 )
.
Goniozus kuriani
sp. nov.
was emerged from the leaf galls induced by
Trioza jambolanae Crawford
( Hemiptera : Triozidae ).
Gordh & Móczár ( 1990 )
listed six species of
Goniozus
associated with plant galls and its inhabitants, many of them were reared from cynipid galls.
Dohanian ( 1942 )
reported that an undetermined
Goniozus
sp. reared from the leaf galls induced by
Cynips maculipennis (Gillette)
( Hymenoptera : Cynipidae ) on
Quercus garryana Douglas ex Hook
( Fagaceae ). This host association needs to be verified as the galls were infested by filbert worm,
Cydia
(=
Melissopus
) latiferreanus (Wlsm.) ( Lepidoptera : Totricidae) very shortly after the primary gall development.

The host-parasitoid interaction of
G. microstigmi (
Melo & Evans 1993
)
could be the association of
Goniozus
with thrips as
Microstigmus
spp. act as a predator of the thysanopterans (
Polaszek & Krombein 1994
). Association between
G. inauditus
sp. nov.
and
Carpelimus
sp. strongly supports the chances for a parasitc relationship between the bethylid and the staphylinid as the species of
Carpelimus
exhibit a predatory behaviour with other organisms. There are association of
Goniozus
spp. with the gall community, which demands critical verification like that of Kurian’s ( 1952 ) report of
G. morindae Kurian
associated with
Asphondylia morindae Mani
( Diptera : Cecidomyiidae ), induces flower galls on
Morinda tinctoria
( Rubiaceae ). There is a strong possibility for
Goniozus
spp. to attack the hosts living in a concealed habitat like plant galls, leaf fold and tree barks etc. apart from Lepidoptera and Coleoptera . This study concludes that the association of bethylids, particularly
Goniozus
spp. with the other members of the gall community, can modify the results of the selective pressure exhibited by the parasitoids on gall inhabitants.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5 . A & B)
Goniozus kuriani Santhosh
sp. nov.
on leaf gall of
Syzygium cumini
.

subSection.paragraph: This work is part of a research project funded by Department of Science and Technology, Government of India under SERB-Young Scientist Scheme (SB/YS/LS- 42 / 2014 ). We are grateful to the authorities of Malabar Christian College, Calicut for providing the facilities. We are thankful to Giulio Cuccodoro (Muséum d’Histoire Naturelle, Genève, Switzerland ) for identifying the staphylinid recovered from the galls. Thanks are due to Mamoru Terayama, Celso Azevedo and Arkady Lelej for reviewing and editing the manuscript.
